ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: 12. We need more classes on food and agriculture. This course was mediocre at best, but it was the bestoffered on the topic this year. Yale FES must do better.

A fascinating new course with a fascinating structure. It was great to hear so many perspectives. Gordon reallywas a facilitator more than a teacher. In the future, having 1 instructor for each module would be better than having a different lecture every week. I found the one lecture format not really ideal. The talks were great, but it wasn't really teaching so to speak. A field trip or two would be great as well.I like the course and its subject matter and hope it continues.

I was a little frustrated that the grading scheme changed for the reading responses -- originally, they were much better, and then once it became more of a completion grade, the quality diminished.Maybe if we had to do fewer but better ones, the quality would improve? With the caveat that you can be cold-called in class, and marked down if you clearly haven't done the reading (even if it wasn't your response day)?

I liked the general format of speaker + discussion, but I think the order should be switched next year, so that we can discuss the speaker rather than preview. There would be much more to be said I bet. I loved the final project and hearing about other peoples. Perhaps more time should be devoted to presenting on that. I found we didn't have enough time to give a good presentation. Maybe no final speaker and 2 full class days of this?

I really enjoyed the class overall. But as with most food related classes, it is hard to come away with real take-homes. This is the first year of this course, and I hope to see this class improve next year.
Many of these questions don't apply because the course was structured around guest speakers.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Some of the speakers were great. The tomato section was the strongest.
Good group of speakers
Interesting range of topics.
The range of perspectives, the critical topic, exposure to a range of practices. Cara Mae.
The project was a good way to delve deeper into a topic we touched on in the course.
Having an excellent variety of guest speakers on a wide range of different but related topics.
Great work course organizers. Thank you for doing this.
Some of the guest lecturers were excellent, but it's really hard to ensure that someone will be a good speaker and be ontopic.
The speakers were (usually) great.
Having professionals and practitioners in the field coming to speak with us directly about the issues and specific commodities.
The guest lectures.
Hearing the guest speakers who were eloquent, getting to work on a research project

The class really encouraged a high level of student participation and involvement (in class discussion and weekly reading responses), which helped me think about the concepts from the readings/lectures in more depth. The course was well-organized and was able to tie together the 4 different commodities. The guest lecturers were, for the most part, informative and interesting. I do not have an agriculture background, so this course was a great way for me to "get my feet wet" in the topic.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: More structure in the discussion sessions, and a sharper focus on possible solutions.

I felt that there was a little too much emphasis on technical information. This is a generalist class and most people are not going to be subject matter experts (and certainly not through this class) so I think the focus should be more on general strategy and positioning rather than the ins and outs of some technical issues.
Some speakers were very poor presenters. The room was too big and poorly laid out for quality presentations and discussion; most people were on their laptops the whole time.

Logistical challenges that led to a sense of discontinuity...sometimes difficult to really absorb. I was too busy to really do the readings fully and that would have helped. I tended to rush through the reading responses. The readings were really well curate though, with a few exceptions.
Some of the speakers were not quite what I expected.
More connections between the lectures, or in the future casting a slightly less "wide" net.
Discussion could stagnate sometimes. What about assigning students to be discussion leaders for topics that they really enjoy, or areas in which they have expertise?
I didn't love the readings, but I'm not quite sure what would be better.

Discussion should be more focused on the reading, since that's the common body of knowledge we all had about the issues at hand. We should also reflect more on the speakers, which we did towards the end.

a wider range of guest speakers, I think having more people from the private sector and government would have been more beneficial than having NGOs dominate the speaker listthe reading responses - the specific questions were too constraining, I often found myself skimming to find the answers rather than reading the entire section. I think having boarder questions would have been more beneficial.I would remove the tomato component, I felt that they were too rushed and it would have been more beneficial if we have less modules and more time on each individual one

More time should be spent in defining mitigation options for agriculture. Also, more time is needed to define how students graduating from FES may have the most impact in mitigating agricultural impacts. For example, we discussed a lot of technical approaches to mitigating agriculture, but I am still usure of our role in increasing the use of these technologies.Also, I think the group projects should be more limited and perhaps linked to client opportunities with some of the guest lectures. This would help to connect the class discussion more with the long term projects/papers.

The seminar portion of this course needs improvement. No one in the room was an expert on the material, as it was centered around guest lectures, which made discussions unfocused. Both instructors were often very hands off about leading discussion, which I felt made the seminar run worse. I usually left seminar not feeling I had learned much of anything.To make it better, I think either the course would have to be partially restructured, or someone would need to lead discussion with a stronger hand and with more pre-discussion planning. For course structure, having discussion that follow the lectures, instead of precede them, would allow for the class to process and delve into that talk and would provide more framing for the discusison.

I would suggest that the order of the discussion section and the lecture be reversed. I think class discussions were not very helpful this semester, and I feel that they would be much more rich if everyone had already heard the lecture beforehand (ie, Tuesday = lecture, Thursday= discussion section). I would also have liked for some of the lectures to talk about the environmental issues surrounding their commodity in more detail, while focusing less on one specific technology. John Volpe's first lecture, for instance, gave a great overview of the issues surrounding salmon production. Lastly, I thought the reading responses with the more general/broad questions were the most helpful, because they helped me hone in on the topics that were most interesting to me and that I wanted to focus on. Also, one of the weekly response prompts should be to create questions for the next lecture.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Yes. We prepared for the upcoming speaker by familiarizing ourselves with the issues they were going to present.
N/A
I was in the 1 credit option without discussion.
It was effective and useful to discuss the guest lecture on a given week both before and after it had occurred.
Yes, very effective. I especially liked when we planned out questions for the speaker, so that the speaker would have some guidance before seeing us about what our expectations were.
The discussion section was not very helpful, I think in part because we all only had the readings to go off of. Listening to the lecture first would have made for much more interesting discussions.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am very interested in the subject matter and it was great to have the wide variety of speakers come into class. I am looking for a career in food/agriculture and I am very glad that this class was available and that Cara Mae and Gordon put so much work into making it happen. Thanks!
I hope to work in sustainable food and ag after Yale.

This is right up my alley. I liked the organiztion of the class into commodities, but I think future versions of the class could be less a series of presentations, and more an actual expert in this field just teaching the class. there are benefits and drawbacks to each. The class contributed to my knowledge of agriculture at the large scale, how its actually done in the world, which was great, as my previous exposure was primarily small scale sustainable. Figureing out where these meet in a less techincal and more rigorously political way might also be good. Food is more than just commodity, but I do appreciate learnign the metrics and values used to discuss ag at the large scale.
For someone interested in food and ag, it was great to finally have a course to tackle these issues directly, and from more practioner perspectives.

It fit into my plan of trying to take as many food-related classes as possible. I think, in the end, it made me realize that the way I feel about the food system is perhaps too radical for the Forestry School, which is a little too reformist/conservative, if this class is any indication.

This course is directly linked to my focus on food systems - food production, distribution, and purchasing. This course did cover an ambitious and sometimes overwhelming amount of material - food marketing, GMOs, aquaculture, carbon credits, labeling, international industry groups, etc. While exposure to all these concepts is wonderful, it was hard to go deeper in certain areas, even with extra readings. Everything felt very rushed.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to learn more about specific methods to mitigate agriculture's impact, and to broaden my exposure to the food world.
Career interest in food/ag, guest speaker component is what drew me in. I took the 1 credit version and would not have taken it if it didn't include the guest speakers.
To network with speakers and other Yalies with an interest in food and ag issues; to get an overview of the topics covered.
learn language and practice of agricultural mitigation. learn about sustainability metrics.
I'm always excited when agriculture-related courses are available, since there are so few.
In line with my areas of interest
To study food and the food system!
To have the chance to take a food course with peers also interested in food.
I was looking to generally learn about food and farming, specifically about the links in the food system for a variety of crops, and how they can be improved.

Not having an agriculture background, I wanted to be exposed to environmental issues in agriculture in order to have a deeper personal understanding of our food system and to help me be a more sustainably-conscious consumer.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I don't feel that I came out with anything I can return to later, but I learned a lot and have the tools to deepen my understanding of particular topics later.
No.

Yes and no. I definitely learned a fair amount, but would have liked more integration, chance to make more connections between readings and strategies, in addition to really precise technical details. I did like all the exposure to different industries and practices, and how sustainability metrics are generated and compared.
I gained an overall awareness of a range of agricultural issues, but not an in-depth knowledge or skill.
Yes and no. As I mentioned, I feel like I got exposed to a lot of material and new research and issues. But I am am still unsure of what specific skills to take-away from this course.

Not quite. I feel that what I learned was shallower than I expected, because we jumped topics so much without bridging between each week, and because discussion did not successfully dive further into the material

Yes, I feel that I have a deeper knowledge of some of the issues in the food system and of how to be a more environmentally conscious food consumer. However, I feel that in some of the units, the course focused too much on specific technologies, since I was more interested in getting a broader understanding of the larger issues behind the production of these 4 commodities.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: 2 heads are better than 1.
N/a
It was advantageous to learn more deeply about a subject covered in the class.
Group work was great and helped us to achieve a better project.

The disadvantage was that I didn't get to know my project partner well enough before working with them and we turned out to not be very compatible. I probably would've preferred working alone. It's hard to write a paper between multiple people, I think. The advantage is that we were able to share research.
It's great to have someone else to plan and discuss with, but as our schedules get busy it is harder to truly collaborate, and we end up working separately and then stitching our parts together.
It was great to work with a partner of the final project.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Try to focus on the technical for your project, since you won't get as much of it in the discussions.
I would advocate the 1 credit version.
Take the 3 credit if at all.
Do the readings early in the week so you can choose what you actually want to focus on. Write about that.

It would be a great course for someone new to the field of food/ag and interested in what sorts of avenues/issues to explore further in their studies. However, it did not go into issues in-depth re: those with more of a deeper background/interest
Make sure you want to take the class for the right reasons, and not just because you want to take afood class.
Heavily invest in the readings and do background research on the speakers.
have an idea about a project early on in the semester. especially if the speakers are related to your project topic
Take the course, the course provides an excellent opportunity to meet interesting speakers and provides opportunities to learn about new innovations and food issues.

This course has a lot of potential, the guest speaker format is intriguing and interesting, and the topics are fascinating. It is great to have a class focused on concrete strategies. However this year the discussion portion of the class was weak, which hurt my experience, so check in with how the discussion will be structured this year before taking it. Also, next year will have a different lead instructor (cara mae won't be there), which will significantly change how the course works and runs.
Write your final paper in the format that you think will best development your professional skills (ie, policy memo, etc), instead of just doing yet another academic paper.
